results.title: What Do We Want?
results.creator_credit: Carlo Zeccola, Molly O'Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.credit_line:
2022
Reko Rennie, Kamilaroi
Three-channel video
Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
results.brief_description: What Do We Want draws on 1970s Blaxploitation films and Rennie’s own martial arts practice to explore political, environmental and social questions through an Aboriginal Australian lens.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Carlo Zeccola, Molly O’Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.description:
An army of First Nations warriors come out to play in this latest action-packed video by Kamilaroi artist Reko Rennie.

An all-Indigenous crew of martial arts students train together in their dojo; learning teachings of discipline, self-defense and teamwork. When the Sensei cries, “What do we want?” the students respond, “Restitution! Land back! Equality! No more cops killing our mob!”, vocalising demands of environmental, political and social concern, and reflecting the broad diversity within contemporary Indigenous urban society.

Rennie was taught martial arts by his father while growing up in Melbourne’s inner West. What Do We Want? marries his 25-year history of martial arts and his arts practice, while expanding Rennie’s evolving moving image repertoire into the realm of performance.

What Do We Want? takes influence from martial arts films including Blaxploitation films of the 1970s and 80s; utilising the medium to make a statement about authenticity, respect, bravery and collective power. The students in What Do We Want? become a force to be reckoned with.

Displayed in the gallery in a massive three-channel video installation, the work loudly and proudly conveys the diversity of First Nations peoples, and the ongoing fight for justice that unifies them, raising urgent questions that require action and response.

Acknowledgements

results.title: 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector
results.brief_description: Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector.

constellations_primary.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_primary.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

results.description:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!
description_for_label:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!

results.title: The Mansion [game trailer]
results.brief_description: It’s a moonless night… Let’s go explore a mansion. In ‘The Mansion’, a nameless character finds himself with the task of searching an old mansion. Although he can’t understand the lost children it doesn’t take a true connection to know only he can help. The story is told through a platformer format, inspired by games such as Super Mario Bros.

results.title: Connecting

results.brief_description: Grandma Swift laments her disconnectedness from the outside world, a quick idea takes a comical journey through modern and old time methods of communication leading to a modern day twist at the end.

results.title: Voyager [game trailer]
results.brief_description: In a faraway world lived two clans, Dezminus and Akai. Their only connection was a trade route, trading Dezminus’ ores for Akai’s wheat. But one day Dezminus’s food supplies stopped coming. So Dezminus decided to declare war and conquer the Clan of Akai. So they sent a warship to declare war on Akai. The captain of that vessel was…you.

results.title: Big Game
results.creator_credit: Jarrod Hasenjager and The Animation School (Cape Town)
results.brief_description:
Bobo, a lonely monster, is set to spend another birthday alone, until a cunning monster hunter throws him a killer surprise party!
Animators: Sarah Scrimgeour, Aarin Lehmkuhl, Romy Latter, Miro Kolenic, Jarrod Hasenjager, Matthew Furnell.

Production Designers: Jarrod Hasenjager, Sarah Scrimgeour, Romy Latter
Sound: Andrew Schar, Kamil Govender
